Corresponding results for outcome 1: Political dialogue, peace advocacy and violence prevention enhanced
1. The project supported validation and signing of 3 separate Codes of Conduct (CoC) by representatives of 18 political parties and their respective wings of youths (All Political Parties Youth Association) and women (All Political Parties Women’s Association). This committed political parties and aspirants (including women and youth) to peaceful and violence free elections, 2. Supported a high-level dialogue forum which concluded with all presidential candidates signing the Peace Pledge. This committed the presidential candidates to peaceful campaigns and acceptance of results. 3. Supported the NCD sustained non-violence campaigns to promote a peaceful electoral period. At least 18 open public sensitization events on non-violence were conducted in 18 constituencies. NCD also conducted at least 48 outreach sessions on voter education in 16 districts targeting first-time voters, women, and PWD. A total of 4,016 participants (2,627 men & 1,389 women) were provided with practical knowledge on the voting process. 4. The NCD through the Citizen’s platform established in 2017 organized at least 7 bi-weekly meetings reaching over 280 participants. This helped to spread the message of non-violence. 5. The Human Rights Commission of Sierra Leone (HRC-SL) trained at least 109 members of the District Human Rights Committees (DHRC) in 4 regions including 38 women and 71 men. The HRC also conducted community engagements on human rights in 4 regions reaching at least 155 participants (37 males & 118 females) including market women, political party representatives, youth groups, teachers, students, the police among others. This ensured that messages on human rights and peaceful elections were promoted across the country during and after the election period. 6. To enhance access to justice for rights’ holders, including women and vulnerable groups, the Legal Aid Board (LAB) provided legal aid to at least 363 clients (13 women and 350 men) on election related issues and provided legal counselling and referral services to 111 complainants of electoral related offences. 7. To further enhance access to justice, the Judiciary trained over 50 legal staff from the Legal Aid Board (LAB) and the Sierra Leone Bar Association (SLBA) and deployed them to support litigation of electoral offenses/cases and represent persons in civil cases. Additionally, the Justice App, initially developed with support of the UNDP Bail and Sentencing project, was also enhanced through inclusion of functions for all Electoral Offenses. This system was used to track and process a total of 27 cases through the supreme court (5); High Court (12); and magistrate courts. 8. To sustain peace during post-election period, 4 initiatives were implemented at sub-national level including (i) community healing & reconciliation, (ii) Inclusive dialogue supported by referral systems, (iii) creation of awareness and (iv) research on drivers of violence. At least 11 districts have benefited from the support.
Corresponding results for outcome 2: Public security, civil protection, human rights promotion and peaceful response capacities sustained
1. To strengthen national and community-based Early Warning and Response Systems, the Project supported the Office of National Security (ONS) conduct at least 3 election security simulation exercises. This provided a practical understanding to the security personnel from different security formations in Sierra Leone’s security sector including the police, military, custodial corps, etc. It also enabled the security institutions to support the election processes at strategic, tactical and operational command levels. The exercises further provided a practical understanding the protective work and services of security personnel and organizations in support of the election process at strategic, tactical and operational levels of command. Existing plans were validated, procedures tested, and staff competencies enhanced by providing them with practical experiences to more easily execute their roles. At least 330 security personnel participated. 2. The project supported the ONS strengthen operational capacity of the Integrated Elections Security Planning Committee (IESPC) greatly contributing to national Early Warning and Response Systems. 3. To enhance community-based structures on Early Warning and Response, at least 14 town hall meetings were conducted by ONS in 14 districts to disseminate key messages on election security reaching over 700 beneficiaries. The meetings helped build trust between security personnel and citizens as well as build capacity of ONS staff during the electoral cycle. 4. To build the capacity of the Sierra Leone Police (SLP), over 3,000 police officers were trained on election security management, conflict prevention and mitigation as well as human rights. The Human Rights component was facilitated by a member of HRC-SL with technical advice provided by OHCHR. 5. To ensure early monitoring mechanisms were in place, the project furnished 6 Incident Command and Control Centers (ICCs) of the Sierra Leone Police in the 6 regions of Sierra Leone. These ICCs played a leading role in enhancing communications and dissemination of information between and among SLP personnel in the regional centers and the headquarters.

Output 1.2: Sustained non-violence campaigns conducted and messages on human rights and peaceful elections promoted across Sierra Leone.
1. White paper developed laying a foundation for discussions and deliberations on establishment of peace infrastructure foe Sierra Leone. 2. Three dialogue fora identified and resolved conflicts and tensions emanating from elections in 9 districts. 3. The ministry of Political and Public Affairs (MPPA) conducted nationwide consultations which culminated into a national conference on peace and social cohesion in May 2019 which solicited views from various stakeholders (government, Civil society sector, members of political divide, experts etc). The MPPA worked in collaboration and consultation with the Office of Vice president and the chief minister to balance peace building and social cohesion agenda after elections.
Output 1.2: Sustained non-violence campaigns conducted and messages on human rights and peaceful elections promoted across Sierra Leone.
1. At least 20 new Chiefdom Security Committees (CHISECs) were established and trained in 12 districts of Sierra Leone.
